clinical_study.brief_title: Addition of Nitrous Oxide and Its Effects on Depth of Anesthesia
clinical_study.official_title: Addition of Nitrous Oxide to a Sevoflurane or Propofol Based Anesthetic and Its Effects on Depth of Anesthesia Indices (N20)

brief_summary.textblock: The study hypothesizes that adding 60% nitrous oxide to a steady state sevoflurance or propofol anesthetic will lead to a decrease in both BIS and Entropy indices during a constant level of surgical stimulus

detailed_description.textblock: Nitrous oxide is a widely used general anesthetic pas. It is often used in addition to a second, more potent agent. BIS and Entropy are depth of anesthesia monitors in clinical use. There are conflicting reports about the usefulness of these monitors when nitrous oxide is used as a part of the anesthetic regimen. While some studies demonstrate a decrease in BIS and Entropy, this study aims to investigate the effects of adding nitrous oxide to a sevoflurane or a propofol based anesthetic on BIS and Entropy indices.

primary_outcome.measure: to demonstrate the effectiveness of two commonly used depth of anesthesia monitors (BIS & Entropy) on measuring the anesthetic effects of a commonly used anesthetic gas (nitrous oxide)

intervention.description: Addition of 60% nitrous oxide for 20 minutes duration, then back to 1:1 oxygen/air mixture.
BIS Monitor electrodes placed on forehead
Entropy monitor electrodes placed to forehead

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ages 18 to 55yrs
- ASA status less than and equal to 2
Exclusion Criteria:
- Surgery on head and neck
- ASA greater than 3
- Contraindication to nitrous oxide
- Pregnant women
- History of dementia and stroke, or other organic brain disorder
- Prisoner
- Ear surgery
